title: Episode 76 â€“ Charles Orgbon III, Deloitte, Environmental Liability & Sustainability Consultant
subtitle: Sarah Arao Mantle of Hope- Thank You Video to the Y on Earth Community for GoFundMe Campaign Support
full_transcript:
[8.9s - 14.9s]: Hey friends, this next podcast episode is with Charles Orbong from Deloitte.

[15.3s - 22.3s]: We recorded this before the COVID outbreak, so I just want you to know that the pandemic

[22.3s - 24.6s]: wasn't yet on our radar at the time.

[24.9s - 25.6s]: I hope you enjoy.

[26.6s - 32.0s]: Welcome to the Y Honors Communities Stewardship and Sustainability Podcast Series.

[32.8s - 35.9s]: Today, we are visiting with Charles Orbong the third.

[36.2s - 36.7s]: Hi, Charles.

[38.3s - 38.6s]: Hey!

[39.4s - 40.2s]: How are you doing?

[41.5s - 41.8s]: Good.

[42.0s - 45.8s]: It's a pleasure to be on the show and talking about these important issues.

[46.3s - 48.8s]: I'm really excited to have this opportunity to talk with you, Charles.

[49.8s - 56.4s]: So, Charles Orbong the third is a consultant with Deloitte's Risk and Financial Advisory Services,

[56.9s - 59.7s]: where he specializes in environmental liability.

[60.5s - 66.0s]: Charles develops enterprise solutions for his Fortune 500 and public sector clients that

[66.0s - 74.1s]: improve business processes, maximize revenue, manage costs, address risks, strengthen relationships,

[74.1s - 79.4s]: and boost performance while also mitigating social and environmental impacts.

[80.1s - 85.7s]: Before joining Deloitte, Charles gained almost a decade of nonprofit management and leadership

[85.7s - 90.9s]: experience with various environmental philanthropy and youth volunteerism organizations.

[91.7s - 98.5s]: For example, Charles developed and led Greening Forward from 2008 to 2017, which became

[98.5s - 103.5s]: and continues to be a leading organization in the United States that's devoted to training

[103.5s - 107.3s]: and funding student environmental leaders ages 5 to 25.

[108.3s - 113.2s]: Leveraging this experience, Charles also served as a strategy consultant for numerous government

[113.2s - 115.3s]: agencies, foundations, and nonprofits.

[116.5s - 121.4s]: Charles' work in the sustainability and nonprofit leadership space is validated by over 31

[121.4s - 128.0s]: local, national, and international awards, five book mentions, and over 100 speaking

[128.0s - 129.9s]: engagements since 2010.

[130.8s - 136.3s]: And Charles is currently writing a young adult memoir called My Name Isn't Charlie

[136.9s - 140.8s]: about his intersectional identity as a queer black man.

[141.3s - 145.3s]: You can follow his writing journal at CharlesOrbond.com.

[145.6s - 150.1s]: Charles, it's such a pleasure to have you on the show today, and I'm really excited

[150.1s - 152.2s]: to dive into our conversation.

[152.2s - 158.5s]: And I think to get started, I just want to ask, what's your connection to the environmental

[158.5s - 160.8s]: movement and how did you get started with it?

[161.7s - 162.1s]: Certainly.

[162.8s - 168.5s]: In 2008, I was just 12 years old when I founded and led Greening Forward, which you mentioned

[168.5s - 169.0s]: earlier.

[169.6s - 175.9s]: It's an organization that has now grown to become one of the largest and longest running youth

[175.9s - 178.6s]: driven environmental organizations in the country.

[179.2s - 182.9s]: And Greening Forward is composed of high school and college students.

[183.4s - 185.8s]: And we're doing grassroots environmental activism.

[185.8s - 193.8s]: I left the organization in 2017, but I continue to serve a new generation of leadership that's

[193.8s - 197.9s]: helping to guide things forward for the organization.

[198.9s - 203.8s]: Students everywhere are witnessing the effects of climate change, such as our prolonged

[203.8s - 209.1s]: fire seasons and melting permafrosts and intensified storm seasons.

[209.6s - 215.0s]: And in the wake of realizing what's going on, students are also recognizing that our

[215.0s - 216.2s]: future is not secure.

[217.0s - 222.2s]: So Greening Forward provides an opportunity and outlet for those young people to be a part

[222.2s - 227.8s]: of the solution, to not just be witnesses of our changing climate, but to actually be

[227.8s - 231.2s]: solutionaries and creating a new possibility.

[231.7s - 237.6s]: For the longest, I have thought that activism looked like Martin Luther King Jr., and Caesar

[237.6s - 242.8s]: Chavez, and the Lorax, and that was the only way we could make a difference as to grassroots

[243.5s - 244.0s]: organizing.

[244.9s - 250.0s]: But I also realized through working with Greening Forward and some of our corporate partners,

[250.3s - 257.7s]: there's also a lever to be examined at the corporate level as well, that individuals working

[257.7s - 262.7s]: at the community level on behalf of people in opposition to mass and systems are so important.

[263.2s - 268.8s]: But we also need people who understand these issues in those massive systems to create

[268.8s - 270.0s]: change as well.

[270.7s - 277.9s]: And so that's when I started looking at making the transition to the corporate sector to scale

[277.9s - 279.9s]: the impact of my activism.

[280.6s - 288.8s]: And as activists, we must understand that that lever is available to us as well, just like working

[288.8s - 292.6s]: in NGOs or philanthropy and government as well.

[293.0s - 298.8s]: It will need to use all of these tools that are available to us and build as many partnerships

[298.8s - 300.6s]: and coalesces as possible.

[301.1s - 304.7s]: So now I'm making an impact in the corporate space as an environment.

[306.1s - 307.7s]: It's so exciting.

[307.8s - 312.7s]: And it's such a positive and hopeful story and evolution in your career pathway.

[312.8s - 318.1s]: And I have to admit, I love the Lorax in high school actually bit a paper on the Lorax

[318.1s - 323.1s]: and Dr. Sousa's writings related to environmental and social priorities in our time.

[323.1s - 330.8s]: And I mean, it's a huge shift that you made going from that NGO and philanthropic work

[330.8s - 333.8s]: into your work with Deloitte.

[334.1s - 340.2s]: And I'm curious from your vantage point, do you think corporations truly care about climate change?

[341.1s - 344.6s]: Yeah, that's such an important question to Aaron.

[345.1s - 350.0s]: A lot of people in the nonprofit space now that I work in the corporate space,

[350.0s - 353.8s]: they find clever ways of asking Charles, do you still believe in climate change?

[354.7s - 360.1s]: It's hard for them to imagine that corporations do care because I mean,

[360.3s - 366.2s]: we have to recognize that corporations have been responsible for some terrible things

[366.2s - 371.8s]: that have largely affected society such as in Ron and the deep order Verizon Oldspill.

[372.1s - 376.0s]: And I'm just not a fan of the puppy dog filter on social media either.

[376.5s - 386.6s]: But at the same time, corporations can wield the power to also create social and environmental change as well.

[387.2s - 392.6s]: And that's what we're realizing that there's greater importance on these kinds of conversations

[392.6s - 393.9s]: in the corporate sector.

[394.3s - 399.3s]: And we can just look to, for example, the unprecedented shareholder activity

[399.3s - 404.6s]: in the 2017 proxy season that said a clear message to shareholders want to fully understand

[404.6s - 406.9s]: how climate change will impact their business.

[407.2s - 411.7s]: We can look at the sustainability accounting standards board investor uptake.

[412.2s - 415.3s]: So our investors are considering a board level risk.

[415.7s - 421.8s]: If we don't have a plan about climate change or we're not addressing our supply chain

[421.8s - 425.8s]: or we're not trying to reduce our impacts on the environment.

[426.3s - 430.9s]: Or the global reporting initiatives update standards is helping to give us some share

[430.9s - 436.1s]: language about how do we report sustainability and how do we talk about it.

[436.4s - 441.2s]: Our financial sustainability boards task force on climate related financial disclosures,

[441.5s - 448.8s]: the TCFD and their recommendations or what the stock exchange is doing around NASDAQ ESG guidance.

[449.2s - 454.3s]: So the reality is that corporations can't afford to ignore what's going on.

[454.7s - 460.2s]: When a soda company, for example, things about its product strategy, it has to consider

[460.2s - 463.4s]: that product is made up of 99% water.

[464.1s - 470.0s]: And the company can't choose to ignore how climate change will drastically change water availability

[470.0s - 472.2s]: around the globe in the coming decades.

[472.8s - 474.6s]: So that's a risk to business.

[475.4s - 477.3s]: So corporations have to care.

[479.4s - 485.6s]: It's just amazing to hear some of the kind of perspectives and some of the drivers motivating

[486.2s - 492.3s]: folks. And I'm curious. I would imagine a lot of our audience perhaps are familiar with

[492.3s - 496.5s]: things like the sustainability accounting standards board, but probably a bunch of folks

[496.5s - 503.6s]: aren't as familiar. I'm curious. What are those mechanisms actually doing now and how is that

[503.6s - 509.3s]: changing the global economy in a way that maybe we didn't see five or 10 years ago?

[510.2s - 517.9s]: Sure. So these are all tools that corporations can use to help figure out what's material for them.

[518.0s - 523.3s]: What do they want to report on? How do they think about their sustainability strategy?

[523.9s - 530.2s]: And when I say material, every company is making an impact in the environment very different ways.

[530.6s - 538.8s]: The way that a tech company impacts the environment and its people is very different than consumer

[538.8s - 546.2s]: goods or the hospitality and travel industry. And so when we think about materiality, we must think

[546.2s - 551.8s]: about how do we create environmental programs and solutions that are going to be addressing

[551.8s - 557.2s]: the biggest ways we're contributing to environmental degradation.

[558.1s - 565.8s]: So all of say sustainability accounting board standards and GRI are examples of giving us a

[565.8s - 570.9s]: framework for thinking about how do we talk about sustainability and what's important,

[571.1s - 573.9s]: where do you want to see our impact as a company?

[575.8s - 582.0s]: It's really interesting to hear about. You obviously have a role in helping corporations move

[582.0s - 588.2s]: the needle trials, but what about when you're dealing with companies and institutions where

[588.2s - 593.3s]: the employees themselves don't have a clear sustainability responsibility?

[594.1s - 603.5s]: Sure. I would say that the biggest opportunity for any company that wants to be more sustainable

[603.5s - 610.3s]: and think more about how it's creating an impact in the lives of other people and the environment

[611.3s - 618.1s]: is to first think about their company culture. I feel like that's that is a missed opportunity

[618.1s - 624.3s]: if we're not thinking first about company culture around these issues because if the culture exists,

[625.0s - 631.8s]: I believe that the internal pressure can be exerted to move the company further, to move the

[631.8s - 638.9s]: needle further on some of these issues. And I like to tell employees in any organization whether

[639.5s - 645.3s]: you're a nonprofit organization or you're a for-profit organization or the government.

[646.1s - 654.3s]: The good news is you don't need a formal title such as Chief Sustainability Officer or

[655.3s - 662.0s]: Social Impact Manager to do good and drive good in your company. Whether you care about

[662.0s - 667.8s]: transitioning the economy to adjust clean energy future or creating transportation solutions

[667.8s - 674.4s]: that reduce our national depends on fossil fuels, there are actually clever ways to hold

[674.4s - 680.6s]: those passions and still create impact no matter what you do from 9 to 5. Every employee

[680.6s - 687.6s]: holds passions, values, beliefs, fears and we show up to work, we're allowed to bring our humanity

[687.6s - 698.3s]: with us. So if you're an accountant, if you're a janitor, if you are the CEO or anyone in between,

[699.3s - 707.2s]: you can help create that culture within your company to care about these things and start to

[707.2s - 714.1s]: identify opportunities internally that you can take on and drive that can help move your company

[714.1s - 722.0s]: forward. Yeah, I love this. There's such a strong message and narrative of empowerment in what

[722.0s - 727.8s]: I'm hearing and I'm picturing this diagram, this image where you have a corporation and you have

[727.8s - 733.1s]: shareholders on one end becoming even more concerned and active about what's going on with the

[733.1s - 739.1s]: social and environmental stewardship. And then on the other end you have consumers, you have

[739.1s - 745.0s]: customers increasingly paying attention to corporate practices and then in the middle within the

[745.0s - 751.8s]: organization you have employees increasingly taking on leadership roles to help make change

[751.8s - 759.0s]: from within it. It's such an exciting dynamic and really a beautiful way of thinking about how

[759.0s - 766.9s]: those ecosystems are working in those corporations. And you know, I'm wondering what about when

[767.7s - 774.3s]: you're encountering people and employees who aren't necessarily feeling activated around these

[774.3s - 780.7s]: issues or perhaps aren't seeing that they have a role to play or perhaps even don't care much about that.

[784.9s - 794.2s]: So if you want to be happy in your work, there becomes a time where you can begin to examine

[795.2s - 803.9s]: what power you have to change the things that you don't like or to fill a greater connection to your

[803.9s - 811.3s]: work as well. And so the term is called job crafting actually. When employees can create their

[811.3s - 816.4s]: own work streams and follow their passion projects and their employees have either asked for permission

[816.4s - 823.0s]: or simply volunteered anyways to lead campaigns that are changing the purchasing behavior of their

[823.0s - 827.8s]: business units so that services and products, for example, are sourced with a special emphasis on

[827.8s - 833.7s]: sustainably sourced or locally owned and minority owned businesses or there are companies that

[833.7s - 841.8s]: are phasing out plastic straws from their corporate cafeterias or there are employee initiatives

[842.9s - 849.4s]: around investing 401k and pension plans from extractive economies such as oil and gas. There are

[849.4s - 856.2s]: employees and who are encouraging meetings to be vegetarian or vegan because annual agriculture

[856.2s - 863.1s]: has a significant impact on environmental quality or they're launching well-being and sustainability

[863.1s - 872.5s]: campaigns that encourage biking to work. So these kinds of projects can really help someone who's not

[872.5s - 879.3s]: feeling a strong connection to their work or feel like they're making a difference. These projects can

[879.3s - 884.9s]: help them begin to create new possibilities for their work and their job.

[886.2s - 891.8s]: Yes, this is really cool. So what I'm hearing is that as we at the individual level,

[891.9s - 896.8s]: you know, take more responsibility really for our own happiness and well-being within the context

[896.8s - 903.4s]: of our corporate job, one of the ways we can cultivate that is by becoming more engaged and active

[903.4s - 908.7s]: in some of these ways we can help to make a difference. And I think it's a wonderful message.

[910.0s - 915.6s]: I have to check to give one quick shout out to some of our friends doing work in the regenerative

[915.6s - 923.8s]: ag arena with responsible regenerative animal husbandry and that when we're talking about veganism

[923.8s - 929.2s]: and vegetarianism, it's so important to have this robust dialogue around some of these other

[929.2s - 935.6s]: dietary choices and clearly all of our food and beverage choices are having tremendous impacts on

[935.6s - 940.9s]: soil, on water, on the health and well-being of communities all around the planet. And so it's

[940.9s - 945.1s]: I think really important that we're really cultivating an informed, sophisticated

[946.0s - 951.1s]: conversation on this thing. So I just have to give that kind of shout out as we work with so many

[951.1s - 955.7s]: regenerative farmers throughout the country and really work on those issues.

[958.7s - 967.6s]: It is maybe one of the easiest things that we can do to make a difference in the environment is

[967.6s - 973.8s]: reduce our meat consumption. And one of the things that we're working on in the Deloitte office is

[975.3s - 983.3s]: piloting ways of a project to encourage people to not order beef essentially. Distance

[983.3s - 990.7s]: incentivize people from ordering beef for meetings. And we're calculating the impact of that because

[991.8s - 996.9s]: beef of all of the meats are the most land intensive in water and energy intensive.

[998.4s - 1003.6s]: Yeah, I so appreciate that and I know also that a lot of our friends that are doing the soil

[1003.6s - 1010.9s]: building work are actually working with sustainably managed cattle and that sort of thing. So it's

[1010.9s - 1016.9s]: it's a big conversation and obviously we won't dive deeply into that right now but I think it's

[1016.9s - 1023.9s]: amazing that you're helping to push the envelope and have these change making

[1024.7s - 1031.1s]: options and activities available to your colleagues. And I'm wondering at your

[1031.9s - 1039.5s]: work at the Deloitte office in San Francisco, what have been some of the most interesting

[1040.1s - 1045.5s]: job crafting tasks that you have helped to bring to the company Charles?

[1046.6s - 1054.5s]: Sure. Yeah, so there's in my role a client-facing aspect and then an internal aspect. So client

[1054.5s - 1062.3s]: facing is how do we think about sustainability and environmental challenges within our clients?

[1063.2s - 1072.3s]: And then internally our Deloitte practitioners, how do we make sure that our business operations

[1072.3s - 1081.3s]: are as sustainable as possible? And part of it is this in the San Francisco office is me and another

[1081.8s - 1086.5s]: colleague and I came together and we created the sustainability business resource group

[1087.5s - 1092.9s]: for our San Francisco Bay Area and all of the offices that are around San Francisco.

[1093.5s - 1099.4s]: Where we're helping to influence practices and attitudes within our office. But we first

[1099.4s - 1104.9s]: actually realized that we needed to build our community. So we got the approval to send out

[1104.9s - 1110.8s]: a comprehensive survey and the survey allowed us to understand what the practitioners already

[1111.4s - 1116.1s]: understand that Deloitte was doing and what could we do more and who want it to be involved

[1116.1s - 1124.4s]: and helping Deloitte move forward. And so that allowed us to identify a few people too who

[1124.4s - 1131.4s]: became some of our first members and now we're driving work streams that are looking at how can we

[1131.4s - 1138.2s]: reduce our energy consumption in office? I can re-make sure people know how to compost. That's

[1138.2s - 1146.9s]: actually been a challenge for us. How to compost in San Francisco and so our role as a business

[1146.9s - 1152.6s]: resource group is to teach our practitioners what that means. We've brought in some pretty

[1152.6s - 1161.6s]: cool dynamic speakers to also engage our Deloitte community around ways that they can be more

[1161.6s - 1171.4s]: sustainable at home as well as in the office. And soon we'll be diving more into community

[1171.4s - 1180.9s]: engagement as well. That is so exciting and I love the focus on the compost and that's one of the

[1181.6s - 1186.9s]: big focal points for our work through the Wyners community for community mobilization, climate

[1186.9s - 1192.3s]: action, soil regeneration. It's really interesting especially in the urban environment that

[1193.3s - 1198.8s]: composting is more easily done in some settings than in others and as we're recording this,

[1198.8s - 1205.7s]: we're writing the holiday season in my daughter and her boyfriend asked actually for a worm composting

[1205.7s - 1213.3s]: bin for their urban apartments in St. Louis. And it's so cool that that's one of the strategies

[1213.3s - 1219.5s]: that we can deploy in the more urban settings where maybe we don't have access to the yard or the

[1219.5s - 1225.9s]: land that we might find in other settings. And it's obviously such an important day to day thing we

[1225.9s - 1231.2s]: can all be doing to reduce our greenhouse gas emissions, methane emissions from landfills,

[1231.3s - 1235.9s]: while also contributing to the soil building that helps draw down carbon from the atmosphere.

[1236.6s - 1246.2s]: And I love hearing that you guys are focused on that as well. I'm wondering, go ahead, Charles.

[1247.4s - 1252.5s]: Well in San Francisco, the city makes it super easy for us because composting is the law.

[1253.2s - 1262.1s]: So in some respects, being an environmentalist in San Francisco is easy. But we're, you know,

[1262.1s - 1267.9s]: Deloitte works around the world. Deloitte works all across the United States. And what we're doing in

[1267.9s - 1273.4s]: in San Francisco can also be replicated in other cities as well. And so we're seeing that. Like

[1273.4s - 1280.7s]: our idea with the survey and helping to first establish a baseline level of like awareness

[1282.2s - 1286.8s]: has already been replicated in several offices and folks have asked us how how,

[1286.8s - 1290.9s]: how did you get those folks to come into your office and talk to your, talk to the

[1290.9s - 1297.2s]: deloiterers about sustainability. And so that's something else that's really cool about starting

[1298.0s - 1305.3s]: these kind of grassroots internal grassroots internally campaigns is that you can then collaborate

[1305.3s - 1313.2s]: with other people if your company has other offices and spread what you've learned and your

[1313.2s - 1322.1s]: resources and the materials you've built. And so that helps build the culture, right? That helps

[1322.9s - 1329.7s]: send a message to the leadership that folks care about this. And this needs to be something that

[1329.7s - 1335.4s]: we as a company need to be thinking about. And so again, the importance of all of that is that

[1335.4s - 1341.0s]: corporations wield a lot of power to create change. And again, I think the missed opportunity is how

[1341.0s - 1348.1s]: individuals in that company who may not, who may not clearly see themselves as a sustainability

[1348.1s - 1355.6s]: person can still make a huge difference. Like the people who are on our business resource group

[1355.6s - 1364.6s]: do not have a client-facing role in this topic like I do, but they're still making an impact.

[1365.3s - 1371.5s]: Yeah, that's so beautiful. Well, and I love the message around the collaboration with other

[1371.5s - 1379.0s]: organizations. And of course, that is the 17th and final of the United Nations, the Global Communities,

[1379.0s - 1384.6s]: Sustainable Development Goals, collaborating with other organizations. And that's probably a good

[1384.6s - 1390.9s]: segue to remind our audience that this is the Why on Earth Communities Stewardship and Sustainability

[1390.9s - 1398.0s]: Podcast series. And today we are visiting with Charles Worgman III from Deloitte from their

[1398.0s - 1404.9s]: San Francisco office where he's in the risk and financial advisory services. And want to give

[1404.9s - 1409.9s]: it a quick shout out to some of our sponsors and partners who make this series possible. That

[1409.9s - 1419.1s]: includes Patagonia, Purium, Earth Coast productions, Walei Waters, Equal Exchange, the LIDGE Family

[1419.1s - 1425.6s]: Foundation, and Alpine Botanical. So a huge thanks to all of you for your support of our

[1426.4s - 1432.9s]: work, both the podcast, digital media resources, and the on-the-ground in-person community mobilization

[1432.9s - 1438.3s]: activities that we're bringing to communities all around the country. And I also want to give a

[1438.3s - 1444.1s]: huge shout out to all those individuals out there who have joined our monthly giving program.

[1444.7s - 1449.3s]: And if you haven't yet joined and you want to, you can join at any level. You just go to

[1449.3s - 1455.4s]: Y-Hunter.org, click on the donate or support links and you'll get to the spot where you can select

[1455.4s - 1460.4s]: the amount you'd like to give on a monthly basis. If you want to give at certain levels to get

[1460.4s - 1467.2s]: some of the rewards, just give me a hauler and I'll make sure you know all about the programs that

[1467.2s - 1475.7s]: we have there for you. And Charles, it's just wonderful to hear about the leadership that you

[1475.7s - 1481.5s]: and that Deloitte are deploying throughout the world with all of these different corporate and

[1481.5s - 1488.1s]: organizational connections that you all have. And I'm wondering, when you're thinking about

[1488.1s - 1493.7s]: employees at other firms who may also want to establish similar programs to what you've

[1493.7s - 1497.9s]: established at Deloitte, what advice would you have for them?

[1499.6s - 1505.0s]: Well, first, you need a senior leadership ally. This is someone who can work with you to remove

[1505.0s - 1511.4s]: roadblocks and identify firm funding sources and just help make appropriate connections. And we're

[1511.4s - 1517.4s]: we're lucky to have found a partner in our firm Kevin Fried who works to make sure that we're

[1517.4s - 1522.7s]: moving things for it. He's our champion. But second, you must build your community of like

[1522.7s - 1528.6s]: minded professionals for us. The starting point there was using the survey like we like I mentioned

[1528.6s - 1532.8s]: earlier and that worked well because it was sent to everyone in the office and got lots of

[1532.8s - 1538.4s]: responses. But whatever you do, you will need others across other departments to join you in making

[1538.4s - 1544.3s]: an impact. They'll bring important perspectives to the opportunities and you can help and they can

[1544.3s - 1548.7s]: also help add just context to the challenges within company as well.

[1549.9s - 1555.7s]: That's so cool. There are two key terms in our discussion today that I just love and I'm

[1555.7s - 1561.2s]: starting to hear more and more one being solutionaries and the other being job crafting. And I'm

[1561.2s - 1568.1s]: wondering what are some of the other levers of job crafting that you're seeing and that you've

[1568.1s - 1578.0s]: utilized? Yeah, so job crafting could be thinking about your role and differently.

[1578.0s - 1586.2s]: And so the examples before of like taking on this project or using your power, maybe you're

[1586.2s - 1594.6s]: already creating a catering order, right? But like using your power to choose a caterer that

[1594.6s - 1601.7s]: sources their products locally, right? Or like these are ways that we can also job craft and

[1601.7s - 1609.1s]: just thinking about our role differently and the resources and helping to use the resources of

[1609.1s - 1616.3s]: our company to make an impact. But also you could job craft your relationships. You can change

[1616.3s - 1621.7s]: the nature or extent of your interaction with other people. What I mean by that is when we

[1621.7s - 1626.5s]: build deeper intentional relationships with our colleagues, we can learn and grow while also

[1626.5s - 1632.8s]: deepening our sense of greater purpose. So this is really, I think that's really important too,

[1632.9s - 1637.6s]: is like before we can create change within corporations we have to actually know who we're working with.

[1637.8s - 1646.0s]: So I think building those meaningful relationships is really important. And then we also can job craft

[1647.8s - 1654.3s]: our perceptions. Now that I work at Deloitte, I find myself in rooms with many accountants and I'm

[1654.3s - 1660.1s]: the sole person with a sustainability background and naturally accountants have expressed their

[1660.1s - 1666.9s]: happiness to me, especially around busy season, of course. It's such a such a wild time of the year

[1666.9s - 1673.6s]: for an accountant and an accountant at a large firm for instance might choose to think of her job

[1673.6s - 1679.9s]: as two separate parts. One not particularly enjoyable like staring at hundreds of pages of

[1680.0s - 1686.0s]: documentation dealing with hospital clients or one very meaningful part creating a more responsible

[1686.6s - 1693.3s]: business climate for which our entire economy is based upon like an accountant is so necessary.

[1694.3s - 1701.9s]: So I think that how we perceive the work is also really important too. Even when I was running

[1701.9s - 1706.9s]: greening for and I was working in a nonprofit space there were certainly times where I did not feel like

[1706.9s - 1714.9s]: I was making impact because doing work still means that people are going to say no or that some

[1714.9s - 1719.7s]: people are going to be difficult to work with and it doesn't matter if you're in the nonprofit

[1719.7s - 1727.4s]: space working with kids to make a difference or you're working with billionaires to help them figure

[1727.4s - 1732.7s]: out how can they reduce their environmental impact right. So there's still going to be challenges

[1732.7s - 1739.4s]: with every job. So thinking about the percept how we perceive the work is really important as well

[1739.4s - 1744.7s]: because it's likely that everyone's job is making impact. It's just something you have to

[1746.8s - 1754.6s]: it may not be clear to us all the time. Well so you're I mean you're really working in a lot of

[1754.6s - 1760.9s]: different channels and you're up to so much and on top of all this you're also writing a memoir

[1761.5s - 1768.4s]: right and as I mentioned earlier it's called my name isn't Charlie and does the memoir have a

[1768.4s - 1776.2s]: connection to sustainability? Sort of the the memoir manuscript is already written but writers

[1776.2s - 1784.2s]: are in the business obviously of like constantly rewriting than writing so I'm currently looking

[1784.2s - 1790.0s]: for a literary agent. Yes you're you're also an author as well so I know you can relate to that.

[1790.5s - 1797.1s]: The memoir discusses my coming of age as a queer black man in the south and it finds comedy and

[1797.1s - 1804.6s]: what was actually a pretty difficult childhood. It's a story that discusses my mom's mental illness

[1804.6s - 1810.5s]: and poverty and bullying racism and how that all affected me and ultimately the mission is that

[1810.5s - 1819.2s]: we can save a young person's life who's contemplating suicide like I once did when I was a teen

[1819.2s - 1824.4s]: who will read it and discover that there are other options and the future is so much brighter.

[1825.2s - 1831.8s]: My dad actually read the manuscript and it was so powerful to him that he was once super homophobic

[1831.8s - 1839.4s]: and since lightened up and it's finally began to accept me for my complete identity so

[1840.5s - 1846.9s]: I think that that's a really great sign. I'm really happy in what the writing has already done.

[1847.6s - 1855.2s]: I'm also looking for literary agent representation at the same time and hopefully we'll be

[1857.6s - 1862.9s]: I'm sure it will catch the interest of a publisher and we'll be traditionally published.

[1863.6s - 1868.7s]: Yeah that's that's really wonderful to hear and certainly as a fellow writer I can appreciate

[1868.7s - 1877.4s]: the process. It takes a lot to create and share a book and you know I'm just struck. I know a handful of

[1878.3s - 1883.9s]: white folks from the south who really struggled with that culture growing up and of course to be

[1884.9s - 1892.1s]: a person of color from the south that's a whole other level of challenge and struggle that I think

[1892.1s - 1900.4s]: a lot of Americans perhaps don't fully appreciate Charles and to also be a person with a queer

[1900.4s - 1906.8s]: identity on top of that. I mean it's clearly I would imagine that in the memoir you're sharing that

[1906.8s - 1912.7s]: there were a number of times that were extremely painful for you and I think it's so important

[1912.7s - 1918.9s]: for that kind of story to be shared with the broader world and here you are despite all of those

[1918.9s - 1926.3s]: challenges with an amazing career doing all kinds of great work with all kinds of different people

[1926.3s - 1932.6s]: throughout the country and worldwide and they're such a hopefulness in that message and in that

[1932.6s - 1938.6s]: story Charles I'm just really grateful you're sharing that with folks. Thank you.

[1939.7s - 1946.3s]: But actually to answer your earlier question about the connection to sustainability I think my

[1946.3s - 1953.6s]: path into sustainability in a writer are both expressions of my activism. They're both things that

[1953.6s - 1959.9s]: need to be addressed the inequality that exists in our world that he spoke of and then also

[1959.9s - 1966.0s]: that we need to work together to really create a more sustainable solution for a lot of the

[1966.0s - 1972.7s]: problems that we're facing. So I like to think my life is more meaningful when I'm devoted to a

[1972.7s - 1980.6s]: cause through passionate activism and I look to Alice Walker's quote where she says activism

[1981.1s - 1990.0s]: is my rent for living on the planet. Yeah so I love that quote I'm um bear with me I'm going to

[2028.6s - 2034.5s]: I want to remind our audience they can go to Charlesorgbond.com to follow with your writing journal and

segments.text: Hey friends, this next podcast episode is with Charles Orbong from Deloitte.
We recorded this before the COVID outbreak, so I just want you to know that the pandemic
wasn't yet on our radar at the time.
I hope you enjoy.
Welcome to the Y Honors Communities Stewardship and Sustainability Podcast Series.
Today, we are visiting with Charles Orbong the third.
Hi, Charles.
Hey!
How are you doing?
Good.
It's a pleasure to be on the show and talking about these important issues.
I'm really excited to have this opportunity to talk with you, Charles.
So, Charles Orbong the third is a consultant with Deloitte's Risk and Financial Advisory Services,
where he specializes in environmental liability.
Charles develops enterprise solutions for his Fortune 500 and public sector clients that
improve business processes, maximize revenue, manage costs, address risks, strengthen relationships,
and boost performance while also mitigating social and environmental impacts.
Before joining Deloitte, Charles gained almost a decade of nonprofit management and leadership
experience with various environmental philanthropy and youth volunteerism organizations.
For example, Charles developed and led Greening Forward from 2008 to 2017, which became
and continues to be a leading organization in the United States that's devoted to training
and funding student environmental leaders ages 5 to 25.
Leveraging this experience, Charles also served as a strategy consultant for numerous government
agencies, foundations, and nonprofits.
Charles' work in the sustainability and nonprofit leadership space is validated by over 31
local, national, and international awards, five book mentions, and over 100 speaking
engagements since 2010.
And Charles is currently writing a young adult memoir called My Name Isn't Charlie
about his intersectional identity as a queer black man.
You can follow his writing journal at CharlesOrbond.com.
Charles, it's such a pleasure to have you on the show today, and I'm really excited
to dive into our conversation.
And I think to get started, I just want to ask, what's your connection to the environmental
movement and how did you get started with it?
Certainly.
In 2008, I was just 12 years old when I founded and led Greening Forward, which you mentioned
earlier.
It's an organization that has now grown to become one of the largest and longest running youth
driven environmental organizations in the country.
And Greening Forward is composed of high school and college students.
And we're doing grassroots environmental activism.
I left the organization in 2017, but I continue to serve a new generation of leadership that's
helping to guide things forward for the organization.
Students everywhere are witnessing the effects of climate change, such as our prolonged
fire seasons and melting permafrosts and intensified storm seasons.
And in the wake of realizing what's going on, students are also recognizing that our
future is not secure.
So Greening Forward provides an opportunity and outlet for those young people to be a part
of the solution, to not just be witnesses of our changing climate, but to actually be
solutionaries and creating a new possibility.
For the longest, I have thought that activism looked like Martin Luther King Jr., and Caesar
Chavez, and the Lorax, and that was the only way we could make a difference as to grassroots
organizing.
But I also realized through working with Greening Forward and some of our corporate partners,
there's also a lever to be examined at the corporate level as well, that individuals working
at the community level on behalf of people in opposition to mass and systems are so important.
But we also need people who understand these issues in those massive systems to create
change as well.
And so that's when I started looking at making the transition to the corporate sector to scale
the impact of my activism.
And as activists, we must understand that that lever is available to us as well, just like working
in NGOs or philanthropy and government as well.
It will need to use all of these tools that are available to us and build as many partnerships
and coalesces as possible.
So now I'm making an impact in the corporate space as an environment.
It's so exciting.
And it's such a positive and hopeful story and evolution in your career pathway.
And I have to admit, I love the Lorax in high school actually bit a paper on the Lorax
and Dr. Sousa's writings related to environmental and social priorities in our time.
And I mean, it's a huge shift that you made going from that NGO and philanthropic work
into your work with Deloitte.
And I'm curious from your vantage point, do you think corporations truly care about climate change?
Yeah, that's such an important question to Aaron.
A lot of people in the nonprofit space now that I work in the corporate space,
they find clever ways of asking Charles, do you still believe in climate change?
It's hard for them to imagine that corporations do care because I mean,
we have to recognize that corporations have been responsible for some terrible things
that have largely affected society such as in Ron and the deep order Verizon Oldspill.
And I'm just not a fan of the puppy dog filter on social media either.
But at the same time, corporations can wield the power to also create social and environmental change as well.
And that's what we're realizing that there's greater importance on these kinds of conversations
in the corporate sector.
And we can just look to, for example, the unprecedented shareholder activity
in the 2017 proxy season that said a clear message to shareholders want to fully understand
how climate change will impact their business.
We can look at the sustainability accounting standards board investor uptake.
So our investors are considering a board level risk.
If we don't have a plan about climate change or we're not addressing our supply chain
or we're not trying to reduce our impacts on the environment.
Or the global reporting initiatives update standards is helping to give us some share
language about how do we report sustainability and how do we talk about it.
Our financial sustainability boards task force on climate related financial disclosures,
the TCFD and their recommendations or what the stock exchange is doing around NASDAQ ESG guidance.
So the reality is that corporations can't afford to ignore what's going on.
When a soda company, for example, things about its product strategy, it has to consider
that product is made up of 99% water.
And the company can't choose to ignore how climate change will drastically change water availability
around the globe in the coming decades.
So that's a risk to business.
So corporations have to care.
It's just amazing to hear some of the kind of perspectives and some of the drivers motivating
folks. And I'm curious. I would imagine a lot of our audience perhaps are familiar with
things like the sustainability accounting standards board, but probably a bunch of folks
aren't as familiar. I'm curious. What are those mechanisms actually doing now and how is that
changing the global economy in a way that maybe we didn't see five or 10 years ago?
Sure. So these are all tools that corporations can use to help figure out what's material for them.
What do they want to report on? How do they think about their sustainability strategy?
And when I say material, every company is making an impact in the environment very different ways.
The way that a tech company impacts the environment and its people is very different than consumer
goods or the hospitality and travel industry. And so when we think about materiality, we must think
about how do we create environmental programs and solutions that are going to be addressing
the biggest ways we're contributing to environmental degradation.
So all of say sustainability accounting board standards and GRI are examples of giving us a
framework for thinking about how do we talk about sustainability and what's important,
where do you want to see our impact as a company?
It's really interesting to hear about. You obviously have a role in helping corporations move
the needle trials, but what about when you're dealing with companies and institutions where
the employees themselves don't have a clear sustainability responsibility?
Sure. I would say that the biggest opportunity for any company that wants to be more sustainable
and think more about how it's creating an impact in the lives of other people and the environment
is to first think about their company culture. I feel like that's that is a missed opportunity
if we're not thinking first about company culture around these issues because if the culture exists,
I believe that the internal pressure can be exerted to move the company further, to move the
needle further on some of these issues. And I like to tell employees in any organization whether
you're a nonprofit organization or you're a for-profit organization or the government.
The good news is you don't need a formal title such as Chief Sustainability Officer or
Social Impact Manager to do good and drive good in your company. Whether you care about
transitioning the economy to adjust clean energy future or creating transportation solutions
that reduce our national depends on fossil fuels, there are actually clever ways to hold
those passions and still create impact no matter what you do from 9 to 5. Every employee
holds passions, values, beliefs, fears and we show up to work, we're allowed to bring our humanity
with us. So if you're an accountant, if you're a janitor, if you are the CEO or anyone in between,
you can help create that culture within your company to care about these things and start to
identify opportunities internally that you can take on and drive that can help move your company
forward. Yeah, I love this. There's such a strong message and narrative of empowerment in what
I'm hearing and I'm picturing this diagram, this image where you have a corporation and you have
shareholders on one end becoming even more concerned and active about what's going on with the
social and environmental stewardship. And then on the other end you have consumers, you have
customers increasingly paying attention to corporate practices and then in the middle within the
organization you have employees increasingly taking on leadership roles to help make change
from within it. It's such an exciting dynamic and really a beautiful way of thinking about how
those ecosystems are working in those corporations. And you know, I'm wondering what about when
you're encountering people and employees who aren't necessarily feeling activated around these
issues or perhaps aren't seeing that they have a role to play or perhaps even don't care much about that.
So if you want to be happy in your work, there becomes a time where you can begin to examine
what power you have to change the things that you don't like or to fill a greater connection to your
work as well. And so the term is called job crafting actually. When employees can create their
own work streams and follow their passion projects and their employees have either asked for permission
or simply volunteered anyways to lead campaigns that are changing the purchasing behavior of their
business units so that services and products, for example, are sourced with a special emphasis on
sustainably sourced or locally owned and minority owned businesses or there are companies that
are phasing out plastic straws from their corporate cafeterias or there are employee initiatives
around investing 401k and pension plans from extractive economies such as oil and gas. There are
employees and who are encouraging meetings to be vegetarian or vegan because annual agriculture
has a significant impact on environmental quality or they're launching well-being and sustainability
campaigns that encourage biking to work. So these kinds of projects can really help someone who's not
feeling a strong connection to their work or feel like they're making a difference. These projects can
help them begin to create new possibilities for their work and their job.
Yes, this is really cool. So what I'm hearing is that as we at the individual level,
you know, take more responsibility really for our own happiness and well-being within the context
of our corporate job, one of the ways we can cultivate that is by becoming more engaged and active
in some of these ways we can help to make a difference. And I think it's a wonderful message.
I have to check to give one quick shout out to some of our friends doing work in the regenerative
ag arena with responsible regenerative animal husbandry and that when we're talking about veganism
and vegetarianism, it's so important to have this robust dialogue around some of these other
dietary choices and clearly all of our food and beverage choices are having tremendous impacts on
soil, on water, on the health and well-being of communities all around the planet. And so it's
I think really important that we're really cultivating an informed, sophisticated
conversation on this thing. So I just have to give that kind of shout out as we work with so many
regenerative farmers throughout the country and really work on those issues.
It is maybe one of the easiest things that we can do to make a difference in the environment is
reduce our meat consumption. And one of the things that we're working on in the Deloitte office is
piloting ways of a project to encourage people to not order beef essentially. Distance
incentivize people from ordering beef for meetings. And we're calculating the impact of that because
beef of all of the meats are the most land intensive in water and energy intensive.
Yeah, I so appreciate that and I know also that a lot of our friends that are doing the soil
building work are actually working with sustainably managed cattle and that sort of thing. So it's
it's a big conversation and obviously we won't dive deeply into that right now but I think it's
amazing that you're helping to push the envelope and have these change making
options and activities available to your colleagues. And I'm wondering at your
work at the Deloitte office in San Francisco, what have been some of the most interesting
job crafting tasks that you have helped to bring to the company Charles?
Sure. Yeah, so there's in my role a client-facing aspect and then an internal aspect. So client
facing is how do we think about sustainability and environmental challenges within our clients?
And then internally our Deloitte practitioners, how do we make sure that our business operations
are as sustainable as possible? And part of it is this in the San Francisco office is me and another
colleague and I came together and we created the sustainability business resource group
for our San Francisco Bay Area and all of the offices that are around San Francisco.
Where we're helping to influence practices and attitudes within our office. But we first
actually realized that we needed to build our community. So we got the approval to send out
a comprehensive survey and the survey allowed us to understand what the practitioners already
understand that Deloitte was doing and what could we do more and who want it to be involved
and helping Deloitte move forward. And so that allowed us to identify a few people too who
became some of our first members and now we're driving work streams that are looking at how can we
reduce our energy consumption in office? I can re-make sure people know how to compost. That's
actually been a challenge for us. How to compost in San Francisco and so our role as a business
resource group is to teach our practitioners what that means. We've brought in some pretty
cool dynamic speakers to also engage our Deloitte community around ways that they can be more
sustainable at home as well as in the office. And soon we'll be diving more into community
engagement as well. That is so exciting and I love the focus on the compost and that's one of the
big focal points for our work through the Wyners community for community mobilization, climate
action, soil regeneration. It's really interesting especially in the urban environment that
composting is more easily done in some settings than in others and as we're recording this,
we're writing the holiday season in my daughter and her boyfriend asked actually for a worm composting
bin for their urban apartments in St. Louis. And it's so cool that that's one of the strategies
that we can deploy in the more urban settings where maybe we don't have access to the yard or the
land that we might find in other settings. And it's obviously such an important day to day thing we
can all be doing to reduce our greenhouse gas emissions, methane emissions from landfills,
while also contributing to the soil building that helps draw down carbon from the atmosphere.
And I love hearing that you guys are focused on that as well. I'm wondering, go ahead, Charles.
Well in San Francisco, the city makes it super easy for us because composting is the law.
So in some respects, being an environmentalist in San Francisco is easy. But we're, you know,
Deloitte works around the world. Deloitte works all across the United States. And what we're doing in
in San Francisco can also be replicated in other cities as well. And so we're seeing that. Like
our idea with the survey and helping to first establish a baseline level of like awareness
has already been replicated in several offices and folks have asked us how how,
how did you get those folks to come into your office and talk to your, talk to the
deloiterers about sustainability. And so that's something else that's really cool about starting
these kind of grassroots internal grassroots internally campaigns is that you can then collaborate
with other people if your company has other offices and spread what you've learned and your
resources and the materials you've built. And so that helps build the culture, right? That helps
send a message to the leadership that folks care about this. And this needs to be something that
we as a company need to be thinking about. And so again, the importance of all of that is that
corporations wield a lot of power to create change. And again, I think the missed opportunity is how
individuals in that company who may not, who may not clearly see themselves as a sustainability
person can still make a huge difference. Like the people who are on our business resource group
do not have a client-facing role in this topic like I do, but they're still making an impact.
Yeah, that's so beautiful. Well, and I love the message around the collaboration with other
organizations. And of course, that is the 17th and final of the United Nations, the Global Communities,
Sustainable Development Goals, collaborating with other organizations. And that's probably a good
segue to remind our audience that this is the Why on Earth Communities Stewardship and Sustainability
Podcast series. And today we are visiting with Charles Worgman III from Deloitte from their
San Francisco office where he's in the risk and financial advisory services. And want to give
it a quick shout out to some of our sponsors and partners who make this series possible. That
includes Patagonia, Purium, Earth Coast productions, Walei Waters, Equal Exchange, the LIDGE Family
Foundation, and Alpine Botanical. So a huge thanks to all of you for your support of our
work, both the podcast, digital media resources, and the on-the-ground in-person community mobilization
activities that we're bringing to communities all around the country. And I also want to give a
huge shout out to all those individuals out there who have joined our monthly giving program.
And if you haven't yet joined and you want to, you can join at any level. You just go to
Y-Hunter.org, click on the donate or support links and you'll get to the spot where you can select
the amount you'd like to give on a monthly basis. If you want to give at certain levels to get
some of the rewards, just give me a hauler and I'll make sure you know all about the programs that
we have there for you. And Charles, it's just wonderful to hear about the leadership that you
and that Deloitte are deploying throughout the world with all of these different corporate and
organizational connections that you all have. And I'm wondering, when you're thinking about
employees at other firms who may also want to establish similar programs to what you've
established at Deloitte, what advice would you have for them?
Well, first, you need a senior leadership ally. This is someone who can work with you to remove
roadblocks and identify firm funding sources and just help make appropriate connections. And we're
we're lucky to have found a partner in our firm Kevin Fried who works to make sure that we're
moving things for it. He's our champion. But second, you must build your community of like
minded professionals for us. The starting point there was using the survey like we like I mentioned
earlier and that worked well because it was sent to everyone in the office and got lots of
responses. But whatever you do, you will need others across other departments to join you in making
an impact. They'll bring important perspectives to the opportunities and you can help and they can
also help add just context to the challenges within company as well.
That's so cool. There are two key terms in our discussion today that I just love and I'm
starting to hear more and more one being solutionaries and the other being job crafting. And I'm
wondering what are some of the other levers of job crafting that you're seeing and that you've
utilized? Yeah, so job crafting could be thinking about your role and differently.
And so the examples before of like taking on this project or using your power, maybe you're
already creating a catering order, right? But like using your power to choose a caterer that
sources their products locally, right? Or like these are ways that we can also job craft and
just thinking about our role differently and the resources and helping to use the resources of
our company to make an impact. But also you could job craft your relationships. You can change
the nature or extent of your interaction with other people. What I mean by that is when we
build deeper intentional relationships with our colleagues, we can learn and grow while also
deepening our sense of greater purpose. So this is really, I think that's really important too,
is like before we can create change within corporations we have to actually know who we're working with.
So I think building those meaningful relationships is really important. And then we also can job craft
our perceptions. Now that I work at Deloitte, I find myself in rooms with many accountants and I'm
the sole person with a sustainability background and naturally accountants have expressed their
happiness to me, especially around busy season, of course. It's such a such a wild time of the year
for an accountant and an accountant at a large firm for instance might choose to think of her job
as two separate parts. One not particularly enjoyable like staring at hundreds of pages of
documentation dealing with hospital clients or one very meaningful part creating a more responsible
business climate for which our entire economy is based upon like an accountant is so necessary.
So I think that how we perceive the work is also really important too. Even when I was running
greening for and I was working in a nonprofit space there were certainly times where I did not feel like
I was making impact because doing work still means that people are going to say no or that some
people are going to be difficult to work with and it doesn't matter if you're in the nonprofit
space working with kids to make a difference or you're working with billionaires to help them figure
out how can they reduce their environmental impact right. So there's still going to be challenges
with every job. So thinking about the percept how we perceive the work is really important as well
because it's likely that everyone's job is making impact. It's just something you have to
